results.brief_description: Traces the career of Viv Richards, one of cricket’s greatest ever batsmen, with interviews. Narrated by Richie Benaud.

results.title: Last chance for the lucky country
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The six programs use archival material, case studies of products and people and comparisons with other nations to show how Australia has fallen behind other nations through not utilizing its intellectual and enterpreneurial talent. The programs are: “Cringe dwellers” tells how some of our world firsts were stolen by more resourceful countries. “The Backward frontiers” looks at rural innovations. “Desperately seeking solutions” compares our research and development with Japan and U.S.A. “Ordinary people, extraordinary ideas” looks at the future of innovation. “Inventing the future” a view of the new breed of entrepreneurs. “Up the J curve” the story of our industrial decay, pointing to the light at the end of the tunnel. Accompanied by one teacher’s guide and student activities.

results.title: Japan behind the mask: a special report by John Pilger
results.brief_description: John Pilger presents a two-part look at the “real” Japan, at working and living conditions, at education, the status of women and at nationalism. Pilger demonstrates that behind the public relations image of a high tech, happy population, employed for life by benevolent big brother companies, lies the private truth of powerless unions, small companies, unemployment, inequality between the sexes, pollution, educational pressure and escalating expenditure on armaments. Yet in spite of all this, the everyday kindness, modesty and grace of the Japanese people is unaffected.

results.title: Black robe
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Robert Lantos, Stephane Reichel, Sue Milliken, Alliance and Samson
results.brief_description: Based on Canadian author Brian Moore’s acclaimed novel, this is the brutal and breathtaking story of two men and their journey deep into the heart of the rugged Canadian wilderness. Struggling to survive, they face the savagery of the native Indians, the perils of their 1,500 mile trek and the hardships of the hostile land. Acclaimed director Bruce Beresford has created an ultimate adventure, a bold and brave story of courageous men journeying into a dangerous land. Stars Lothaire Bluteau and Aden Young.

results.title: Crime and punishment
results.brief_description: Directed by Josef Von Sternberg this is the first English language version of Dostoyevsky’s novel of obsession, murder and guilt. Peter Lorre stars as the criminology student turned murderer and Edward Arnold as the detective who breaks him. This is an example of Hollywood tackling the great Russian epic and achieving it with style.

results.title: Bambi
results.creator_credit: David D. Hand, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.credit_line:
Disney Studio Artist

Story sketch

Coloured pencil and graphite on paper
results.material_description: Coloured pencil and graphite on paper
results.brief_description: Acknowledged by generations of moviegoers as one of the greatest Disney animated classics ever produced, this extraordinary movie miracle is most fondly remembered as Walt Disney’s favourite picture. The simple, heartwarming story of the newborn ‘prince of the forest’ reflects the universal joy in us all as we discover the wonders of life and the beauty of nature. Each new revelation, along with bashful Flower and fun-loving Thumper, elevate this beloved classic to the status of timeless masterpiece. Nominated for five Academy Awards.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David D. Hand, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.description:
Walt Disney Animation Studio’s Bambi (1943) is one of the most visually striking and emotionally resonant and endearing animated features that the studio has ever produced. From the realistic animal animation and vivid, impressionistic backgrounds to the coming-of-age story at its centre, Bambi changed the way the studio approached animation and established one of its signature looks.

Walt Disney famously brought two fawns (baby deer) into the studio to help his animators create realistic illustrations. To get the attitudes and movements of animals in the wild right, he filmed hours of footage for the animators, and even had them study animal anatomy. But the cheerful faces of Bambi, Thumper and Flower were designed by an animator studying the expressions of human babies. When he translated those looks onto the drawings of animals, the adorable and expressive animal faces that have been the hallmark of the Studio’s subsequent films was born. The early concept sketch featured above is one of the earliest examples of this type of animation, and shows Bambi meeting his future friend Flower.

Friendship and love are at the heart of Bambi, which follows the princely deer from birth to adolescence and adulthood, with the trials and hardships of life also never overlooked. Instead, the film teaches audiences how to overcome life’s bitter winters, knowing that spring is always on its way. Apart from containing an ageless wisdom, Bambi is also one of the world’s first environmental films, which considers the destructive intrusion of man on nature, but its overarching message of peace, acceptance and harmony shows audiences there’s nothing love can’t conquer.
description_for_label:
Walt Disney Animation Studio’s Bambi (1943) is one of the most visually striking and emotionally resonant and endearing animated features that the studio has ever produced. From the realistic animal animation and vivid, impressionistic backgrounds to the coming-of-age story at its centre, Bambi changed the way the studio approached animation and established one of its signature looks.

Walt Disney famously brought two fawns (baby deer) into the studio to help his animators create realistic illustrations. To get the attitudes and movements of animals in the wild right, he filmed hours of footage for the animators, and even had them study animal anatomy. But the cheerful faces of Bambi, Thumper and Flower were designed by an animator studying the expressions of human babies. When he translated those looks onto the drawings of animals, the adorable and expressive animal faces that have been the hallmark of the Studio’s subsequent films was born. The early concept sketch featured above is one of the earliest examples of this type of animation, and shows Bambi meeting his future friend Flower.

Friendship and love are at the heart of Bambi, which follows the princely deer from birth to adolescence and adulthood, with the trials and hardships of life also never overlooked. Instead, the film teaches audiences how to overcome life’s bitter winters, knowing that spring is always on its way. Apart from containing an ageless wisdom, Bambi is also one of the world’s first environmental films, which considers the destructive intrusion of man on nature, but its overarching message of peace, acceptance and harmony shows audiences there’s nothing love can’t conquer.

results.title: Free and enterprising
results.creator_credit: Paul Humfress, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Illustrates the factors which are important for small business success and the importance of basic techniques in planning and control which are essential to the survival and growth of the enterprise.

results.title: Play snooker with Dennis Taylor
results.brief_description: Former world champion, Dennis Taylor, covers every aspect of this popular indoor sport. Dennis insists that you must start the right way: understand the rules, find the right cue and take care of it, stand and hold the cue correctly and know when and how to use rests and extensions. And, once you’ve got started, then it is time to learn how to pot, how to control the cue ball, how to play difficult shots and how to develop strategies and tactics.

results.title: Polska
results.creator_credit: David Bradbury, AFFC and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A documentary on contemporary life in and history of Poland. Shows Lech Walensa speaking in public, and has interviews with Poles about daily life in Poland. Recorded in English but contains subtitles in English for spoken Polish. Filmed in colour with some Black & White sequences.
